bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Gustaf E. Lambert, February 26, 1929

div1.p: Kean apologizes for not recalling that Lambert was the nurse who cared for him when he was sick with yellow fever. Kean tells Lambert he should be proud of his service in connection with the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Gustaf E. Lambert, February 26, 1929
div1.opener:
- Copy -
26 February, 1929.
Mr. Gust. E. Lambert,
5101 Kimbark Ave.,
Chicago, Ill.
My dear Mr. Lambert:
div1.p:
I have read your letter of February 21 with a great deal of
pleasure and am glad to know the details of your fine service in con-
nection with the yellow fever work at Camp Columbia. I am a little
ashamed that when your name first came up, I did not recall it as
that of the man who took such faithful care of me when I had yellow
fever, and also looked after Major Edmunds and others who were attacked
by yellow fever at that time. I think it is extraordinary that you did
not get infected at Major Edmunds' house, because as I had lived in that
house I recall that it was not screened. I think I got my infection
from his case I visited him in the early morning the day before he
died, and talked with the nurse through the open window, as General Lee
had ordered me not to visit any more yellow fever cases.

I regret very much that with all your experience in the care
of yellow fever cases you were not oneof those who underwent the exper-
iments of the Reed Board so that you could be included in the list of
the experimental cases which are given pensions. I wish that all of
our fine lads who worked in connection with yellow fever as nurses and
in any other capacities could have been included, but this would have
been quite an indefinite list, and the Committee have decided to limit
the list to those named in the reports as volunteers for the experimental
tests.

You have every reason to be proud of your service in spite of
the fact that you are not on that list. I am sending a copy of this
letter to The Surgeon General for his information and for file.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, J. R. Kean Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.
